messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: A degree 4 sum-of-squares lower bound for the clique number of the Paley graph

Paper Abstract: Abstract We prove that the degree 4 sum-of-squares (SOS) relaxation of the clique number of the Paley graph on a prime number pùëùp of vertices has value at least Œ©‚Äã(p1/3)Œ©superscriptùëù13\Omega(p^{1/3}). This is in contrast to the widely believed conjecture that the actual clique number of the Paley graph is O‚Äã(polylog‚Äã(p))ùëÇpolylogùëùO(\mathrm{polylog}(p)). Our result may be viewed as a derandomization of that of Deshpande and Montanari (2015), who showed the same lower bound (up to polylog‚Äã(p)polylogùëù\mathrm{polylog}(p) terms) with high probability for the Erd≈ës-R√©nyi random graph on pùëùp vertices, whose clique number is with high probability O‚Äã(log‚Å°(p))ùëÇùëùO(\log(p)). We also show that our lower bound is optimal for the Feige-Krauthgamer construction of pseudomoments, derandomizing an argument of Kelner. Finally, we present numerical experiments indicating that the value of the degree 4 SOS relaxation of the Paley graph may scale as O‚Äã(p1/2‚àíŒµ)ùëÇsuperscriptùëù12ùúÄO(p^{1/2-\varepsilon}) for some Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0, and give a matrix norm calculation indicating that the pseudocalibration proof strategy for SOS lower bounds for random graphs will not immediately transfer to the Paley graph. Taken together, our results suggest that degree 4 SOS may break the ‚Äúpùëù\sqrt{p} barrier‚Äù for upper bounds on the clique number of Paley graphs, but prove that it can at best improve the exponent from 1/2121/2 to 1/3131/3.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Finding a large hidden clique in a random graph",
        "Graph matrices: Norm bounds and applications",
        "Spectra of Cayley graphs",
        "The clique numbers and chromatic numbers of certain Paley graphs",
        "A nearly tight sum-of-squares lower bound for the planted clique problem",
        "Squares and difference sets in finite fields",
        "Random graphs",
        "Quasi-random graphs",
        "The cubic moment of central values of automorphic LùêøL-functions",
        "Open problems in additive combinatorics",
        "On the directions determined by a Cartesian product in an affine Galois plane",
        "Explicit SoS lower bounds from high-dimensional expanders",
        "Improved sum-of-squares lower bounds for hidden clique and hidden submatrix problems",
        "On the number of complete subgraphs contained in certain graphs",
        "A combinatorial problem in geometry",
        "Finding and certifying a large hidden clique in a semirandom graph",
        "The probable value of the Lov√°sz-Schrijver relaxations for maximum independent set",
        "A study in sums of products",
        "On the Lov√°sz theta function and some variants",
        "Geometric algorithms and combinatorial optimization, volume 2",
        "Block-diagonal semidefinite programming hierarchies for 0/1 programming",
        "Lower bounds for least quadratic non-residues",
        "Linear lower bound on degrees of Positivstellensatz calculus proofs for the parity",
        "The landscape of the planted clique problem: Dense subgraphs and the overlap gap property",
        "Interlacing eigenvalues and graphs",
        "Clique is hard to approximate within n1‚àíŒµsuperscriptùëõ1ùúÄn^{1-\\varepsilon}",
        "SOS and planted clique: Tight analysis of MPW moments at all degrees and an optimal lower bound at degree four",
        "Explicit lower bounds against œâ‚Äã(n)ùúîùëõ\\omega(n)-rounds of sum-of-squares",
        "On eigenvalues and colorings of graphs",
        "Refined estimates concerning sumsets contained in the roots of unity",
        "Analytic number theory, volume 53",
        "A classical introduction to modern number theory, volume 84",
        "Large cliques elude the Metropolis process",
        "Sum-of-squares lower bounds for sparse independent set",
        "The asymptotic behaviour of Lov√°sz‚Äô theta function for random graphs",
        "Reducibility among combinatorial problems",
        "The probabilistic analysis of some combinatorial search algorithms",
        "Sum-of-squares relaxations for clique number of Paley graphs: Computational aspects, 2018",
        "Expected complexity of graph partitioning problems",
        "Sums of squares, moment matrices and optimization over polynomials",
        "Twisted higher moments of Kloosterman sums",
        "Spectra of graphs with transitive groups",
        "On the Shannon capacity of a graph",
        "On the distribution of Jacobi sums",
        "Linear programming bounds for cliques in Paley graphs",
        "Topics in multiplicative number theory, volume 227",
        "Sum-of-squares lower bounds for planted clique",
        "A random model for the Paley graph",
        "Association schemes, non-commutative polynomial concentration, and sum-of-squares lower bounds for planted clique",
        "Small Ramsey numbers",
        "Tight lower bounds for planted clique in the degree-4 SOS program",
        "Lower bounds for small diagonal Ramsey numbers",
        "On the clique number of Paley graphs of prime power order"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in A degree 4 sum-of-squares lower bound for the clique number of the Paley graph, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
